author: By Rozina Ali
title: The Deadly Red Tape of Israel’s Occupation in Palestine
description: In “A Day in the Life of Abed Salama,” Nathan Thrall untangles the political and personal story of a bus crash on the outskirts of Jerusalem.
content: On a rainy, windy morning in February 2012, on a highway outside of Jerusalem, an 18-wheeler collided with a school bus filled with kindergartners and their teachers. The bus rolled over and landed on its side, door-side down, and burst into flames. One teacher and six children died. Some of the survivors were so badly burned that a local man who broke a window and climbed into the bus to pull the children out couldn’t recognize them as human.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Woolfe
title: ‘Celebrate Jaap!’ the Philharmonic Says as a Maestro Departs
description: The final season of Jaap van Zweden’s brief tenure as music director in New York began with a new suite for the star violinist Joshua Bell.
content: The elements came out for “The Elements.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marcela Valdes
title: Why Can’t We Stop Unauthorized Immigration? Because It Works.
description: Our broken immigration system is still the best option for many migrants — and U.S. employers.
content: ‘We’re getting no support on this national crisis,’ Mayor Eric Adams said in September at a town-hall-style gathering on Manhattan’s Upper West Side. He was talking about the influx of transnational migrants who have landed in the city’s shelter system: more than 118,000 since the spring of last year, with about 10,000 more arriving each month. There are now about 115,000 people in the city’s care, and more than half of them are migrants. In August, the city projected that it would spend $5 billion caring for migrants during this fiscal year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Gornick
title: Ferrante Before Ferrante
description: Elsa Morante’s propulsive 1940s saga of women’s lives, “Lies and Sorcery,” brings its penetrating insight to a new generation.
content: Elsa Morante published “Lies and Sorcery,” a nearly 800-page novel that combines mythic storytelling with Depression-era realism, in 1948, just when postwar literary Italy was embracing the modernist voices of writers like Natalia Ginzburg, Italo Calvino and Morante’s own husband, Alberto Moravia. Nonetheless, it received serious reviews and was a success across Europe. Although an abridged version appeared in America under the title “House of Liars,” the saga was never available in its entirety in English until now, courtesy of New York Review Books, in an inspired translation by Jenny McPhee.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karoun Demirjian
title: Senate Democrat Threatens to Block More of Military Aid to Egypt
description: The new chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee could force the Biden administration to reverse its decision to send Egypt $235 million in military assistance.
content: Senator Ben Cardin of Maryland, the new chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, pledged on Saturday to block the release of $235 million in military aid to Egypt, a move that could force the Biden administration to reverse its decision to prioritize national security interests over Congress’s concerns about the country’s human rights record.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron Boxerman
title: At Least 13 Killed in Nightclub Fire in Spain
description: Spanish authorities are investigating the origins of the blaze, in the southeastern city of Murcia, which also left at least four people wounded from smoke inhalation.
content: At least 13 people were killed on Sunday after a fire broke out in a nightclub complex in southeastern Spain, the authorities said, adding that the number of victims could rise as emergency workers continued to search through the damaged structure.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: Baton Rouge Officers Accused of Covering Up Use of Excessive Force
description: The Baton Rouge Police Department charged three of its officers and a deputy chief with trying to hide their use of stun guns during a strip search.
content: Three officers and a deputy chief of the police department in Baton Rouge, La., were charged with attempting to cover up their use of stun guns during a strip search inside a department restroom, the police chief said on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Blind Spot for Two-Parent Privilege?
description: Readers respond to a column by Nicholas Kristof. Also: Donald Trump’s appeal; diversity statements; artificial intelligence.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Farewell to a Woman in Full
description: Sarah Burton says goodbye to Alexander McQueen with a triumphant collection; Gabriela Hearst departs Chloé.
content: At the end of the Alexander McQueen show, after Naomi Campbell had strutted by in a silver beaded dress with a heart-shape breastplate of a bodice and a skirt dripping in loops of fringe, and the audience had risen to its feet in a standing ovation, the designer, Sarah Burton, came out to take her bow. It would be, everyone knew, her last one for the brand.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins
title: Huge Antigovernment Crowds March in Poland Ahead of Critical Election
description: The fate of democracy and aid for Ukraine undergird the October vote, which will decide whether the governing Law and Justice party secures an unprecedented third term in a row.
content: Huge crowds marched through Poland’s capital, Warsaw, on Sunday, converging around a giant flag commemorating a 1944 uprising against Nazi Germany, as opponents of the governing party sought to rally voters for a critical general election that they see as the last chance to save the country’s hard-won democratic freedoms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Debra Kamin
title: Maybe in Your Lifetime, People Will Live on the Moon and Then Mars
description: Through partnerships and 3-D printing, NASA is plotting how to build houses on the moon by 2040.
content: The moon is a magnet, and it is pulling us back.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Carballo
title: Chipotle Manager Pulled Off Worker’s Hijab, U.S. Says in Lawsuit
description: An official with the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, which filed the lawsuit, said the nature of the allegations was “quite egregious.”
content: An assistant manager at a Chipotle restaurant in Kansas pulled off an employee’s hijab, according to a federal lawsuit that contains allegations of religious harassment that a federal official described as “quite egregious.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Walther
title: The Enemies of Literature Are Winning
description: This is why I hate Banned Books Week.
content: Walk past any bookstore or library in America this week, and you are likely to find a sign exhorting you to “Read a Banned Book.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Scissors Sound
description: Alexandria Mason’s New York Times debut has us spellbound.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Hubbard and Safak Timur
title: Turkey Strikes Kurdish Rebels After Suicide Attack in Ankara
description: “Many terrorists were neutralized,” Turkey said of the airstrikes, which it ordered after the P.K.K. took responsibility for a bomb attack.
content: Turkish warplanes on Sunday struck targets affiliated with a Kurdish rebel organization in northern Iraq, the Turkish Ministry of Defense said in a statement, hours after the separatist group took responsibility for a suicide bombing that wounded two police officers in Ankara, the Turkish capital.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Through Triumph and Tragedy, Feinstein Helped Shape San Francisco
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, Oct. 1, 2023.
content: “She was part of that era when the focus was on legislating, policy and getting things done. I think maybe that has died with her.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karoun Demirjian
title: McCarthy Faces Test as Gaetz Moves to Oust Him for Working With Democrats
description: A day after the Republican speaker turned to Democrats for help passing a stopgap spending bill to avert a shutdown, the far-right congressman promised to try to remove him from his post.
content: Speaker Kevin McCarthy’s leadership position is in peril after his most outspoken Republican critic, Representative Matt Gaetz of Florida, said on Sunday he would follow through on threats to try to remove Mr. McCarthy from the job.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: To Many Americans, Government Dysfunction Is the New Normal
description: As the nation teetered on the brink of a shutdown, its citizens were largely focused on other things.
content: As the nation’s capital seemed to be barreling toward another debilitating federal government shutdown this weekend, America, well, did not exactly seem to be on the edge of its collective seat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Hubler
title: Newsom Vetoes Bill Allowing Workers to Collect Unemployment Pay While Striking
description: The move marks a loss for the state labor federation and disappointed union leaders who had hoped to capitalize on a wave of high-profile strikes in the state.
content: Gov. Gavin Newsom of California vetoed legislation on Saturday that would have allowed workers to collect unemployment pay while on strike, disappointing union leaders who had hoped to capitalize on a wave of high-profile walkouts during the state’s “hot labor summer” this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang and Tatsiana Chypsanava
title: Should Children Join the Killing in New Zealand’s War on Invasive Species?
description: A hunting contest has exposed tensions over which animals deserve protection, who gets to define humaneness and how children should be taught about conservation.
content: The pickup trucks rolled up one by one, ferrying a stream of animal carcasses into the show grounds. Pigs, deer, possums, even feral cats — all would be weighed and showcased, the bigger animals strung on racks, the smaller ones laid out in rows that became heaps as the day went on.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robinson Meyer
title: The Climate Fight Will Be Won in the Appliance Aisle
description: Why I’m worried about the next phase of the Inflation Reduction Act’s rollout.
content: More than a year after its passage, much about President Biden’s climate law, the Inflation Reduction Act, is working.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Corey Kilgannon
title: The Gilgo Beach Suspect May Have Hunted Them. Now They’re Key Witnesses.
description: Investigators are talking to women behind bars who worked as escorts and had encounters with the suspect, Rex Heuermann. They had been ignored for years.
content: Rex Heuermann has been under close and constant watch in a Long Island jail since he was charged in July with killing a succession of women and leaving them wrapped in burlap along an oceanfront road.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: Serbia’s President Rejects Claims of Troop Buildup Near Kosovo
description: Aleksandar Vucic called Washington’s assertions of a “destabilizing” military presence along the border a “campaign of lies” after an attack in Kosovo renewed attention to a territorial conflict.
content: President Aleksandar Vucic of Serbia on Sunday rejected White House assertions that he was engaged in a “destabilizing” buildup of forces along the Kosovo border, which has raised fears that the decades-old conflict between Serbia and its former territory was about to flare.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elian Peltier
title: The Hottest New Accessory in Niger? A Russian Flag.
description: Russia has quietly been distributing its own flags throughout West Africa, where they are now considered “so cool.”
content: Young people in West African capitals wave the flags at protests or as they race through cities on motorcycles. Tailors sew dozens of them a day in the narrow alleys of buzzing markets. Taxi drivers put them on their dashboards.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: Oct. 1, 2023
description: No corrections appeared in print on Sunday, Oct. 1, 2023.
content: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jordyn Holman
title: Gen Z Wants Feminine Care Brands to Just Say Vagina
description: Brands selling feminine care products have dropped the euphemisms to sell to younger consumers. But are they still capitalizing on old stigmas?
content: On a recent July evening in Midtown Manhattan, a trio of teenage girls swooped into the feminine care aisle at Target. Skipping over the boxes of Always and Tampax tampons, they made a beeline to a shelf with sanitary pads from the Honey Pot Company. One asked her friend if she was going to pick out the pads with a “minty sensation.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katrina Miller
title: A Nobel Prize Might Lower a Scientist’s Impact
description: A team of researchers at Stanford find that older scientists are less productive after winning major awards like the Nobel and the MacArthur Fellowship.
content: Winning a Nobel Prize can be a life-changing event. The winners are thrust onto a world stage, and for many scientists the recognition represents the pinnacle of their careers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Orlando Mayorquin
title: Police Chief Who Ordered Raid on Kansas Newspaper Is Suspended
description: Gideon Cody, who orchestrated a widely criticized raid on The Marion County Record, was suspended indefinitely, a city official said on Saturday.
content: The police chief of Marion, Kansas, was suspended on Thursday, more than a month after he ordered raids on the office of a local newspaper and the home of its publisher in an act rarely seen in American journalism, one that was widely condemned by news organizations as a violation of the First Amendment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Natalia Yermak and David Guttenfelder
title: Four Seconds to Impact: On the Front Line With Ukraine’s Snipers
description: In a war built around artillery, tanks, drones and cruise missiles, the role of the sniper, unseen and lethal, occupies an often overlooked but essential part of the battlefield.
content: The Russian position was marked with the blue flag of Moscow’s elite airborne units but the fabric looked almost translucent through the Ukrainian sniper’s scope.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Firestone
title: Against the Wall, McCarthy Does the Right Thing
description: At the last possible moment, Kevin McCarthy earned some credit for keeping the government open. But not a lot of credit.
content: Only an extremely shallow man would repeatedly wait until the last possible moment to do the right thing, no matter how obvious that thing might be. But in today’s Washington, the Republican Party usually doesn’t do the right thing at all, so the House speaker, Kevin McCarthy, deserves some credit for putting his job on the line on Saturday to end the threat of a government shutdown.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SUNDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff
title: They Ran for a Better Life, Straight Into a Wildfire
description: Greek authorities assumed the victims were asylum seekers because no one was looking for missing people locally. And for more than a month, their identities, and the circumstances of their deaths, remained a mystery.
content: As they traversed the harsh, wooded terrain in northeastern Greece, the 18 asylum seekers were presented with an agonizing dilemma: Take the safer route through villages and over highways, but into the arms of the Greek authorities, or travel through the forests and fields being ravaged by Europe’s largest recorded wildfire.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: Trailing in Polls, Conservatives Look to Unleash the ‘Real Rishi’ Sunak
description: The British prime minister is trying to redefine himself as a conviction politician, leaning into the newly potent issue of meeting climate goals without raising costs for hard-pressed Britons.
content: When Rishi Sunak arrived at the Conservative Party’s annual conference on Sunday, it was his first as Britain’s prime minister. The question looming for many attendees in the cavernous venue in Manchester is whether it could also be his last.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Vaye Watkins
title: A Novel of Survival and the Sublime in the Mojave Desert
description: Melissa Broder’s “Death Valley” follows a grieving narrator through her reconnection to the earth.
content: In Thomas Merton’s 1960 translation of the teachings of the fourth-century Christian monks known as the Desert Fathers, “Abbot Lot came to Abbot Joseph and said: Father, according as I am able, I keep my little rule, and my little fast, my prayer, meditation and contemplative silence … now what more should I do? The elder rose in reply and stretched out his hands to heaven, and his fingers became like 10 lamps of fire. He said: Why not be totally changed into fire?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Inside McCarthy’s Shutdown Turnabout That Left His Speakership at Risk
description: The Republican speaker opted to keep the government open the only way he could — by partnering with Democrats — in a surprise reversal that left him as politically vulnerable as ever.
content: Speaker Kevin McCarthy began the final day before a government shutdown pinned against the ropes, facing dim prospects of passing any stopgap funding measure to avert the crisis that was to go into effect when the clock struck 12:01 a.m. on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David French
title: One Reason the Trump Fever Won’t Break
description: Christian nationalism may not be serious, but it’s very dangerous.
content: The more I consider the challenge posed by Christian nationalism, the more I think most observers and critics are paying too much attention to the wrong group of Christian nationalists. We mainly think of Christian nationalism as a theology or at least as a philosophy. In reality, the Christian nationalist movement that actually matters is rooted in emotion and ostensibly divine revelation, and it’s that emotional and spiritual movement that so stubbornly clings to Donald Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roger Cohen
title: Unease in the West as Slovakia Appears Set to Join the Putin Sympathizers
description: The front-runner in the parliamentary vote has pledged “not to send a single cartridge” to neighboring Ukraine, a sign of the flagging European support for a victim of Russian aggression.
content: The victory of Robert Fico, a former prime minister who took a pro-Russian campaign stance, in Slovakia’s parliamentary elections is a further sign of eroding support for Ukraine in the West as the war drags on and the front line remains largely static.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold
title: Nikki Haley Won the Debate Stage. Now, She’s Trying to Win Over Iowa.
description: The former governor of South Carolina, who was ambassador to the United Nations under Donald Trump, now needs to appeal to early state voters.
content: About 15 minutes after Nikki Haley took the stage at a town hall in a Des Moines suburb on Saturday, the former governor of South Carolina and ambassador to the United Nations, was heckled — twice — by men demanding to know her views on Taylor Swift.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stacy Cowley
title: Wall Street’s Most Hated Regulator Faces a Fundamental Threat
description: Rohit Chopra, who leads the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, says he is simply enforcing the law. Bankers call him reckless — a “regulator gone rogue.”
content: Rohit Chopra became one of the most powerful financial regulators by pairing bark with bite. As director of the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, he has attacked — often with a hammer — the perpetrators of what he considers injustices against everyday Americans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Hong, Tracey Tully and William K. Rashbaum
title: Menendez Co-Defendant’s Curious Path From Bad Deals to a Meat Monopoly
description: After emigrating to New Jersey from Egypt, Wael Hana faced a string of business and legal problems. Then his friend started dating a powerful U.S. senator.
content: Just five years ago, Wael Hana was reeling from a string of bad business deals in New Jersey, having tried to launch a truck stop, an Italian restaurant, a limousine service and other companies without ever hitting it big.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Justin Porter
title: Monday Briefing: U.S. Aid to Ukraine Is Uncertain
description: Plus NASA’s plan to build houses on the moon.
content: The U.S. Congress narrowly avoided a government shutdown on Saturday by passing a stopgap spending bill to temporarily keep the government open; however, the bill did not include any additional aid for Ukraine. The White House and leaders of both parties in the Senate pushed for more Ukraine funding to be included, and the failure to do so highlighted the decreasing willingness of some Republicans to fund Kyiv’s war effort.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Stevens
title: When Taylor Swift and Travis Kelce Collided With Prime-Time TV
description: The Chiefs escaped with a win over the Jets on “Sunday Night Football,” but many viewers were watching for shots of a luxury suite.
content: The game on Sunday night between the Kansas City Chiefs and the New York Jets was not expected to be must-see TV, at least from a football perspective.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Owen A. Lamont and Richard H. Thaler
title: ‘Dumb Money’ Exposes the Baffling Allure of Bad Investment Advice
description: Pegged to the movie “Dumb Money,” a discussion of the growing stupidity in the stock market.
content: The new movie “Dumb Money” dramatizes the true story of an unlikely messiah named Roaring Kitty who decides to sink his life savings into shares of the video-game seller GameStop and then praise the stock to his fans. So many people buy GameStop shares that the company’s valuation soars, crushing the positions of professional hedge funds that had bet against it. Thus, a band of lovable misfits triumphs over the Wall Street fat cats.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Tim Wakefield, Pitcher Who Helped Boston Break the Curse, Dies at 57
description: After surrendering a homer that ended the Red Sox run in 2003, he played a critical role in the team’s World Series victory a year later.
content: Tim Wakefield, a right-handed knuckleball pitcher for the Boston Red Sox who in 2004 played a critical late-innings relief role in the team’s winning its first World Series championship in 86 years, died on Sunday. He was 57.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Jacobs
title: Jonathan Lethem Returns to the Borough That Launched Him
description: In “Brooklyn Crime Novel,” the veteran author transports readers to a conflicted time in the old neighborhood.
content: Before “a writer living in Brooklyn” became a tiresome stereotype, there was Jonathan Lethem, who — like Bernard Malamud and Betty Smith before him — was actually born and raised in Brooklyn, giving his portrayals of the place, or a swath of it anyway, a dingy verisimilitude. He knows deep in his bones that a coffee shop is not a Starbucks but a diner, and what it means to take that coffee regular (milk and two sugars), like gas in a car.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Hubler
title: Trailblazer, Role Model, Mentor: Feinstein’s Impact on Women in Office
description: When Dianne Feinstein was elected in 1992, only two women were in the U.S. Senate. There were 25 on the day she died.
content: Dianne Feinstein had several lifetimes’ worth of accomplishments by the time she died on Thursday at 90. She was pivotal in crafting a decade-long bipartisan assault weapons ban. She helped lead the congressional response to the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks and questioned the Central Intelligence Agency for its use of torture. As mayor of San Francisco, she led her hometown through years of tumult.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily C. Hughes
title: A Fitting — and Frightening — Homage to ‘The Haunting of Hill House’
description: Apparitions, black hares and time warps festoon the pages of Elizabeth Hand’s “A Haunting on the Hill,” set in the same moldering mansion as Shirley Jackson’s classic horror novel.
content: As Holly, the protagonist of Elizabeth Hand’s “A Haunting on the Hill,” approaches an imposing, deserted mansion tucked off a remote country road, she drives past a tree stump that’s “choked with poison ivy, a riot of scarlet leaves and white berries.” Though she doesn’t know it yet, the tree that once stood there claimed the life of Eleanor Vance, the tragic lead from the novel’s antecedent text, Shirley Jackson’s wildly influential “The Haunting of Hill House.” And so, a couple dozen pages into the book, Hand makes her first decisive mark on Jackson’s landscape, acknowledging her predecessor while making the house her own. When Jackson left Hill House, the tree was still standing. Hand is here to chop it down.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Oct. 2, 2023
description: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
content: 1. After looking closely at the image above (or at the full-size image), think about these three questions:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse and Catie Edmondson
title: Shutdown Avoided
description: A compromise in Congress averted a government shutdown, but battles over federal spending remain ahead.
content: A government shutdown seemed all but certain. Millions of federal workers and members of the military braced for late paychecks. National parks planned to close.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins
title: What Does a Russia-Leaning Party Win in an E.U. Nation Mean for Ukraine?
description: In much of Europe, the election in Slovakia was seen as a bellwether of mainstream support for Ukraine in its war with Russia. But voters seemed most concerned with pocketbook issues.
content: A Russia-friendly populist party finished first in a crowded field on Sunday in Slovakia’s parliamentary elections, a vote that many in Europe have seen as a bellwether of support for the war in Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: Chris Snow, Hockey Executive Who Publicly Faced A.L.S., Dies at 42
description: The assistant general manager of the Calgary Flames, he was given a year to live in 2019. He and his wife used the time to document life with the disease.
content: Chris Snow, the assistant general manager of the Calgary Flames of the National Hockey League, who, after being diagnosed in 2019 with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, became a prominent advocate for victims of the disease, died on Saturday in Calgary, Alberta. He was 42.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Hubbard, Nimet Kirac and Nicole Tung
title: An Ancient City, Now in Ruins, Struggles to Keep Its Soul
description: Seven months after powerful earthquakes battered the historic city of Antakya in southern Turkey, life feels temporary as residents await reconstruction.
content: The businessman fondly recalled his bakery and cafe in the ancient Turkish city of Antakya, where his staff made bread, cakes and cookies and locals gathered for breakfast, coffee and ice cream.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Sperling
title: Longtime Union Leader Steps Fully Into Hollywood’s Spotlight
description: Duncan Crabtree-Ireland, the lead negotiator for SAG-AFTRA, will be a key player as the guild begins talks with the studios again on Monday.
content: Duncan Crabtree-Ireland, the executive director and chief negotiator for the actors’ union, has spent the past two decades toiling behind the scenes during contract talks. The spotlight, he knows, is for the SAG-AFTRA president, usually a well-known performer like the current office holder, Fran Drescher.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘Before Leaving Town, We Stopped to Get Sandwiches to Eat in the Car’
description: Saving a spot in a long line, pulling weeds in Brooklyn and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David W. Dunlap
title: Close Enough to Call Back
description: One of the rarest editions of The New York Times, from election night in 2000, never made it further than the newsroom.
content: There is a lot of drama in a new history of The New York Times, “The Times: How the Newspaper of Record Survived Scandal, Scorn and the Transformation of Journalism,” by Adam Nagourney, a Times correspondent. Among the most anxious episodes was election night in 2000, which Mr. Nagourney called “a blur of changing headlines and stories rewritten in the space of minutes.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: A Pretty Perfect Pollo Asado
description: Marinated all afternoon, placed on the grill an hour before sunset and served with warm tortillas, rice and beans, hot sauce and lime wedges.
content: Good morning. September played out strangely where I hang out: unreasonably Augustlike at first, and then hard into autumnal damp and gloom. I know we’re nowhere near last licks on grilling season, but there’s something a little valedictory about lighting the fires these days. I feel as if I’m cooking on borrowed time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Wearables, Redefined
description: The love affair between fashion and technology gets revived at Coperni, Anrealage and Junya Watanabe. Will it be any more successful this time around?
content: In 2014 Jony Ive, then the chief design officer of Apple, came to Paris Fashion Week with his Big New Product, the Apple Watch, to convince the fashion crowd that wearables were the future of fashion. That turned out to be not exactly true (at least style-wise), but it hasn’t stopped two former Apple designers, Imran Chaudhri and Bethany Bongiorno, from returning nine years later to try again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Nehamas and Eileen Sullivan
title: With Unrealistic Immigration Proposals, DeSantis and Trump Try to Outdo Each Other
description: In dueling speeches in California, the two Republican candidates pushed for mass deportations, a position that is as extreme as it may be unfeasible.
content: As a presidential candidate, Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida has said he would authorize the use of deadly force against people crossing the border, seek to end the practice of birthright citizenship and send the military to strike against drug cartels inside Mexico, a key ally of the United States, even without the permission of its government.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Husarska
title: Spider Boots, Boxers, Hoverboards: When Ukrainian Troops Ask, We Deliver
description: An army of individuals transport needed nonlethal supplies to Ukrainian military personnel in the field.
content: This past summer, Britain’s defense minister at the time, Ben Wallace, chided Ukraine for not showing enough gratitude for the West’s weapons supplies. “We’re not Amazon,” he said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Han Zhang, Tally Abecassis, Aaron Esposito, John Woo, Sophia Lanman and David Mason
title: The Sunday Read: ‘The Art of Telling Forbidden Stories in China’
description: Many Chinese writers are looking for ways to capture the everyday realities that the government keeps hidden — sometimes at their own peril.
content: As China strove for a larger role on the international stage at the turn of the century, the arrival of the internet and a relatively relaxed political environment spurred a boom in self-expression. Many writers tested the boundaries of Chinese literary culture, experimenting with subjects that were quotidian but taboo on the page: corruption, sexual desire and evolving gender roles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak and Abbie VanSickle
title: A Battered Supreme Court Returns to Confront a Challenging Docket
description: The justices will explore the scope of the Second Amendment, the fate of the administrative state and limits on free speech on the internet.
content: When the Supreme Court returns to the bench on Monday, it will face a docket filled with unfinished business. The justices will revisit issues like gun rights, government power, race and free speech even as they are shadowed by intense scrutiny of their conduct off the bench.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg
title: Ukraine Downplays Uncertainty Over U.S. Support After Funding Bill Passes With No Aid
description: Kyiv expressed confidence that the U.S. would continue to support its war against Russia, even after Congress passed a stopgap funding bill that did not include money for Ukraine.
content: Ukraine’s government said on Sunday it was confident that the United States would continue to support it in its war with Russia, even after the House passed a stopgap spending bill to avert a government shutdown that did not include any additional money for Kyiv.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tanya Sichynsky
title: A Cooking Editor Who Finds Inspiration Everywhere
description: For The Veggie, a New York Times newsletter, Tanya Sichynsky mines her personal life for recipe ideas.
content: If the DVD version of “The Dance,” a live album recorded by Fleetwood Mac in 1997, was playing in the living room of my childhood home, I knew I’d be in for one hell of a meal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tomris Laffly
title: How ‘No One Will Save You’ Terrifies Us With Hardly a Word
description: For the Hulu hit, the director relied on visual and sound cues to create both the scares and the plot. Stephen King and Guillermo del Toro are fans.
content: The nail-biter “No One Will Save You” quietly materialized on Hulu Sept. 22 and became a streaming darling overnight, an apt entrance for a largely dialogue-free chiller about an alien invasion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ron Lieber
title: What Should You Do if Hotels Don’t Warn You About Strikes?
description: There is recourse for customers who arrive at a hotel and are surprised to find a boisterous picket line waiting to greet them.
content: There is no word that quite captures the opposite of hospitality, but I can describe what it feels like.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Seibert
title: At Fall for Dance, Meeting Enthusiasm With Mediocrity
description: The festival, with its variety of styles and cheap tickets, plays to excited audiences. Why can’t it give them better programs?
content: Part of the promise of New York City Center’s Fall for Dance festival, now in its 20th season, has been to lure new audiences to dance. In that spirit, Michael Rosenberg, the theater’s new president and chief executive, has been making curtain speeches before this year’s performances, asking first timers in the house to make some noise, then celebrating the big, raucous response as the sound of the future of live performance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eli Saslow and Erin Schaff
title: He’s a Dab of Glue in a Broken City. Can He Hold It Together?
description: In America’s overwhelmed downtowns, private security guards like Michael Bock have become the solution of last resort.
content: Michael Bock was still on his way into work for his shift as a private security guard when he came upon his first emergency of the day. He drove into downtown Portland, Ore., a little after 6 a.m., and saw a man swinging a hatchet and chasing someone into the street. Bock, 46, pulled over and rolled down his window. “Security!” he yelled. “Can we please settle down?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Marchese
title: Arnold Schwarzenegger Is Here to Pump You Up (Emotionally)
description: “The more powerful you are,” says the action icon, author of a new self-help book, “the more power you have in giving back.”
content: “The more powerful you are,” says the action icon, author of a new self-help book, “the more power you have in giving back.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lazaro Gamio, Alicia Parlapiano, Jasmine C. Lee, Helmuth Rosales, Molly Cook Escobar, Allison McCann, Karen Yourish and K.K. Rebecca Lai
title: How Each Member Voted on the Senate Stopgap Spending Measure
description: The Senate overwhelmingly passed a bill to fund the federal government through mid-November. See how each senator voted.
content: The Senate overwhelmingly passed a bill to fund the federal government through mid-November. See how each senator voted.

author: By Reuters and The Associated Press
title: Nightclub Fire Kills More Than a Dozen People in Spain
description: A blaze broke out at a nightclub complex in Murcia, Spain, causing a section of the building to cave in.
content: A blaze broke out at a nightclub complex in Murcia, Spain, causing a section of the building to cave in.
